Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Unable to push packages to NuGet.org?" (#5065) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
This is a placeholder issue to discuss any issue(s) due to the [recent protocol changes](https://github.com/NuGet/Announcements/issues/10) that was announced early October. We also reached out to all active users on the required changes via mail so that everybody had enough time to react to this `breaking change`. (Also see the [twitter announcement](https://twitter.com/adgrv/status/926140980893442048) early November).

### NuGet client requirements: 

NuGet.org will only accept **push** requests from `nuget.exe` version **4.1.0 and above** or from clients that implement **X-NuGet-Protocol-Version: 4.1.0** and identifies so to NuGet.org through the corresponding header (as explained [here](https://github.com/NuGet/Announcements/issues/10)).

List of known clients that can push packages to NuGet.org:
 
| Client | Requirement | 
| :------------- |:-------------| 
| `nuget.exe` |  [version 4.1.0 or above](https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/latest/nuget.exe) |
| `dotnet.exe` | [version 2.0.0 or above](https://www.microsoft.com/net/download/windows) |
| VS Team Services | NuGet tasks already use 4.1.0 by default. [Use NuGet installer task to get latest compatible version](https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/devops/2017/09/29/using-the-latest-nuget-in-your-build/) |
| MyGet | Already uses the right protocol |
| AppVeyor | NuGet push task uses the right protocol |
| NuGet Package Explorer | [version 3.24 or above](https://www.microsoft.com/store/productId/9WZDNCRDMDM3) |
| Custom client | Should implement the [NuGet.org protocol 4.1.0](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/api/nuget-protocols) |

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Add configuration for user package deletes" (#5063) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Progress on https://github.com/NuGet/Engineering/issues/921.

This PR has no functional impact on the gallery but should give a good picture of what the user package delete feature looks like.

NuGet.org's will probably look like this:
```xml
    <add key="PackageDelete.AllowUsersToDeletePackages" value="true" />
    <add key="PackageDelete.MaximumDownloadsForPackageId" value="125000" />
    <add key="PackageDelete.StatisticsUpdateFrequencyInHours" value="24" />
    <add key="PackageDelete.HourLimitWithMaximumDownloads" value="72" />
    <add key="PackageDelete.MaximumDownloadsForPackageVersion" value="100" />
```

The 125,000 is a value that Karan and I agreed upon based off of the number of downloads in the first 24 hours for the top 500 latest packages in the past 6 months. It is a protective measure we can remove later if we find it too cumbersome. I would like to start on the safe side for this feature and do small adjustments later as we build experience with the feature.

I am doing this feature in small PRs since it is a low priority and I can only work on it between other things.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Organizations: Add owner filter to Manage Packages view" (#5060) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Adds an owner filter to the 'Manage Packages' view. See [spec](https://microsoft.sharepoint.com/:p:/r/teams/NuGet/_layouts/15/Doc.aspx?sourcedoc=%7B3EA306C5-ADCE-4A3D-9455-F87A43293B8B%7D&file=NuGet-Organizations.pptx&action=edit&mobileredirect=true)

Changes include:
- Manage Packages section now uses ko data-binding, based on the pattern in ApiKeys.cshtml
- Cleaned up section headings for consistency, and so it's apparent that the filter only applies to the first section

Screenshot:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15364949/33149850-1776272a-cf86-11e7-937b-a6cf9c8202a5.png)

@joelverhagen Regarding performance, it's not too bad client side. I tested with >1000 and >1500 packages (Microsoft on PROD has ~1500). Server response took 11.38s for 1000, and 21.3s for 1500. Client took ~1s for the initial data-binding, but the filtering was pretty quick. I can share some videos of the response times.

@scottbommarito Per your suggestion, I think we should add paging.... I opened #5059 for this.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Consider adding paging to Manage Packages" (#5059) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: There's a lot of scrolling and long (server-side) response for Manage Packages view when there are a lot of packages. We should consider adding paging to the packages lists.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Not using SAS tokens for public containers read URIs" (#5055) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
With @joelverhagen's help found a nasty issue with SAS tokens for blob storage: if expiration time is not specified generated SAS token is invalid and causes HTTP 403 when blob is accessed with that token *even* in public container (which is accessible without any tokens).

It is unclear from documentation whether expiration time should be specified or not and the class that is used to pass that information uses `Nullable<DateTimeOffset>` for the expiration time, which assumes that it's optional. It isn't.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "NuGet restore extremely slow in large solution targeting UAP 10.0" (#6224) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Hi,

NuGet restore is incredibly slow for me.  I am working on a solution with 600+ projects, when restore is run without a preexisting src.bld directory, the process takes about 10 minutes.  Restore is being done for .NET Framework 4.6 and UAP 10.0.

I've pulled the nuget source code and run the restore process from Visual Studio to try to get an idea of what is taking so long.  There seem to be two main culprits, RemoteDependencyWalker.CreateGraphNode() (in RemoteDependencyWalker.cs), and GraphOperations.Analyze() (in GraphOperations.cs) in this case called from RestoreTargetGraph.Create() (in RestoreTargetGraph.cs).  More specifically RemoteDependencyWalker.CreateGraphNode() seems to recursively traverse a dependency graph, and is running 30,000 - 40,000 times when resolving UAP 10.0 dependencies (.NET Framework dependencies do not seem to result in so many calls, frequenty on the order of magnitude of 100).  Each time takes a substantial fraction of a second, and is happening maybe 10 or so times per project.

I'm still not totally comfortable with what's happening in the code, but I thought I would ask, is this an issue which is known of and is there any possibility or plan to improve perf?  I also noticed that in RuntimeGraph.cs there are a number of comments related to possible perf impacting improvements, would these have any impact on this workload?

Thanks so much in advance for any insight on this!

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "PackageManagement UI depends on VS" (#6222) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
The current PackageManagement UI has dependencies on Visual Studio. This makes it nearly impossible to reuse the WPF controls in other apps that may want to interact with NuGet in a consistent way. For example, NuGet Package Explorer needs a "Package Chooser" dialog. This should be an ideal reusable widget where the output is the selected package. Possibly downloaded and referenced from the local cache as well.

I would like to see the dependency order flipped so that the Visual Studio-specific components reference the non-VS components as this would enable more reuse.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Web.Config Runtime/AssemblyBinding section broken on install/update" (#6220) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem
We have a (self-managed) nuget project that has the following section in its `Web.config`;

```
  <runtime>
    <assemblyBinding xmlns="urn:schemas-microsoft-com:asm.v1">
      <dependentAssembly>
        <assemblyIdentity name="Newtonsoft.Json" culture="neutral" publicKeyToken="30ad4fe6b2a6aeed" />
        <bindingRedirect oldVersion="0.0.0.0-10.0.0.0" newVersion="10.0.0.0" />
      </dependentAssembly>
      <dependentAssembly>
        <assemblyIdentity name="System.Web.Optimization" publicKeyToken="31bf3856ad364e35" />
        <bindingRedirect oldVersion="1.0.0.0-1.1.0.0" newVersion="1.1.0.0" />
      </dependentAssembly>
      <dependentAssembly>
        <assemblyIdentity name="WebGrease" publicKeyToken="31bf3856ad364e35" />
        <bindingRedirect oldVersion="0.0.0.0-1.5.2.14234" newVersion="1.5.2.14234" />
      </dependentAssembly>
      <dependentAssembly>
        <assemblyIdentity name="System.Web.Helpers" publicKeyToken="31bf3856ad364e35" />
        <bindingRedirect oldVersion="1.0.0.0-3.0.0.0" newVersion="3.0.0.0" />
      </dependentAssembly>
      <dependentAssembly>
        <assemblyIdentity name="System.Web.WebPages" publicKeyToken="31bf3856ad364e35" />
        <bindingRedirect oldVersion="1.0.0.0-3.0.0.0" newVersion="3.0.0.0" />
      </dependentAssembly>
      <dependentAssembly>
        <assemblyIdentity name="System.Web.Mvc" publicKeyToken="31bf3856ad364e35" />
        <bindingRedirect oldVersion="1.0.0.0-5.2.3.0" newVersion="5.2.3.0" />
      </dependentAssembly>
    </assemblyBinding>
  </runtime>
```

Which is all auto-generated, nothing we've added in.

```
        <assemblyIdentity name="WebGrease" publicKeyToken="31bf3856ad364e35" culture="neutral" />
        <bindingRedirect oldVersion="0.0.0.0-1.5.2.14234" newVersion="1.5.2.14234" />
      </dependentAssembly>
      <dependentAssembly>
        <assemblyIdentity name="System.Web.Helpers" publicKeyToken="31bf3856ad364e35" />
        <bindingRedirect oldVersion="1.0.0.0-3.0.0.0" newVersion="3.0.0.0" />
      </dependentAssembly>
      <dependentAssembly>
        <assemblyIdentity name="System.Web.WebPages" publicKeyToken="31bf3856ad364e35" />
        <bindingRedirect oldVersion="1.0.0.0-3.0.0.0" newVersion="3.0.0.0" />
      </dependentAssembly>
      <dependentAssembly>
        <assemblyIdentity name="System.Web.Mvc" publicKeyToken="31bf3856ad364e35" />
        <bindingRedirect oldVersion="1.0.0.0-5.2.3.0" newVersion="5.2.3.0" />
      </dependentAssembly>
      <dependentAssembly>
        <assemblyIdentity name="Newtonsoft.Json" publicKeyToken="30ad4fe6b2a6aeed" culture="neutral" />
        <bindingRedirect oldVersion="0.0.0.0-10.0.0.0" newVersion="10.0.0.0" />
      </dependentAssembly>
    </assemblyBinding>
  </runtime>
```


NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe):

- NuGet.exe is used to package.
- VS UI is used to install.

NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx): 4.3.0.4406

dotnet.exe --version (if appropriate):

VS version (if appropriate): 2017 Enterprise (15.4.4)

OS version (i.e. win10 v1607 (14393.321)): Win 10 64-bit Build 14393

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: N/A

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Create an ASP.Net Web Application (Proj 1)

2.  Package with NuGet.exe

3. Install Proj 1 into a new ASP.Net Web Application (Proj 2) via VS UI.

4. Observe that `Web.config` for Proj 2 is oddly formatted and missing `<dependentAssembly>` tags in the `<runtime>` section, preventing Proj 2 from running correctly.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "nuget install package from local source requires lowercases package id" (#6219) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

I'm using NuGet CLI version: 4.4.1.4655
Running Arch Linux with kernel 4.14-2

I created a local source and added a package to it. When listing packages the ID is correct, but to install the package I have to lowercase the package ID. The lowercase id corresponds to the path to the package in the local source. From my understanding nuget package id's should be case insensitive

I am unsure if I am using NuGet incorrectly or if this is a bug. If this is not the correct usage, I would much appreciate it if someone can explain or point me to resources that explain how to set up a feed on the local file system. 

## Repro steps

1. Open a terminal.
2. `mkdir proj`
3. `cd proj`
4. `dotnet new classlib`
5. `nuget spec`
6. Edit the spec file so it's valid. Let's give it the `Product.Package` id and version 1.0.0.
7. `nuget pack -build proj.nuspec`
8. `mkdir local`
9. `nuget sources add -name local -source local/`
10. `nuget add Product.Package.1.0.0.nupkg -source local/`
11. `nuget list -Source local` outputs `Product.Package 1.0.0` as expected
12. `ls local/` outputs `product.package/`
13. a. `nuget install Product.Package` => `> Unable to find package Product.Package`
      b. `nuget install product.package` => 
`> Added package 'Product.Package.1.0.0' to folder '/tmp/proj'`
`> Succesfully installed 'product.package 1.0.0`

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Markdown based documentation for packages" (#9) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
Announcing support for rich markdown based documentation for packages

This feature has following parts:
**1. Ability to associate a markdown documentation to packages (and existing packages)
2. Understand markdown and render it properly on NuGet.org package details page**
3. Ability to associate markdown documentation content while packing the package, from clients
4. Ability on VS client to show this markdown content.

1 and 2 have been implemented as part of 2017 Interns project and released now. Please provide your feedback on the feature - both implemented and pending parts.

| Spec wiki| Discussion issue| 
| :------------- |:-------------| 
|https://github.com/NuGet/Home/wiki/Package-README.md-support|https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/2280|

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Updates to the NuGet.org Terms of Use" (#8) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
Today, we’re updating the NuGet.org Terms of Use and Privacy Statement. As we [announced](https://blog.nuget.org/20170907/Changes-to-NuGet-dot-org-service-management-and-performance-improvements-in-China.html) two weeks ago, the NuGet.org service is now a part of Microsoft. The NuGet open source codebase (both the NuGet gallery and the NuGet client) will remain open source and continue as .NET Foundation supported projects under the same terms as before.

We encourage you to read the full [Terms of Use](https://www.nuget.org/policies/Terms) and [Privacy Statement](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=521839), as well as the [blog post](https://blog.nuget.org/20170907/Changes-to-NuGet-dot-org-service-management-and-performance-improvements-in-China.html) about the changes. For your convenience, below is a quick summary.

There are no changes to the way you publish and consume packages from NuGet.org. The Terms of Use and Privacy Statement have been updated to reflect the change in ownership, as well as how Microsoft will process the data collected, and manage copyright and trademark infringement notices.

Our goal is to provide an agile and reliable global service, and we remain fully committed to ensuring a healthy and open ecosystem around NuGet. The .NET Foundation and Microsoft want NuGet to meet the evolving needs of our community. For questions about our policies, please contact us by email at [feedback@nuget.org](mailto:feedback@nuget.org?subject=Regarding%20updates%20to%20the%20NuGet.org%20Terms%20of%20Use).
